channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Former employees said the Las Vegas Raiders organization is in disarray, citing executive departures, poor financial management, unpaid electric bills and a raft of firings, payouts and NDAs. https://t.co/ZMNuoAJrUp

Mike Pence will go to Georgia to headline a rally for Gov. Brian Kemp the day before the state’s primary election, Kemp’s campaign said. Donald Trump has endorsed Kemp's opponent, and criticized him for refusing to overturn Georgia's 2020 election results. https://t.co/A0InjgeVui

Palestinians gathered at the Palestinian Authority’s presidential headquarters to mourn Shireen Abu Akleh, the Al Jazeera journalist who was fatally shot in the West Bank on Wednesday.
“The bullet killed a piece of all of us,” one mourner said. https://t.co/ElhqYp8GfB https://t.co/7kgKTwKhS4

Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has forced Sweden to recalculate its military position after more than 200 years of neutrality.
Pulled along by its strategic partner, Finland, it is expected to apply, reluctantly, to join NATO. https://t.co/HiOJ0VRN8i

Fred Ward, the versatile actor who played an astronaut in “The Right Stuff,” a grizzled drifter in “Tremors” and the titular writer in “Henry and June” across a decades-long career, died on Sunday. He was 79. https://t.co/4YyJPHXMu6

Leni Robredo, the outgoing vice president of the Philippines, acknowledged on Friday her loss in one of the most consequential presidential elections in the nation’s history, urging her supporters to accept the results and to keep fighting disinformation. https://t.co/8lYrY5VEYK https://t.co/rJLieC5L8y
In a first for underwear, the FDA has authorized vanilla-flavored panties to be considered protection against sexually-transmitted infections during oral sex. https://t.co/V6WTZ4fLXe

Shireen Abu Akleh, a trailblazing Palestinian journalist, was fatally shot on Wednesday while covering an Israeli army raid on the Jenin refugee camp in the West Bank. https://t.co/17a5mwjLFY https://t.co/uEYciiV9ip

Breaking News: The Texas Supreme Court ruled that state officials can resume abuse investigations of parents who provide certain medical treatments to transgender children, reversing a lower court’s decision. https://t.co/cRXg7Kepmc

Video showed Israeli police officers in Jerusalem beating and kicking mourners next to the coffin of Shireen Abu Akleh, an Al Jazeera reporter who was killed on Wednesday. Israel said they were “forced to act” after rocks were thrown. https://t.co/jsRnb9DO22 https://t.co/9DokPP9XUd

Leni Robredo, the outgoing vice president of the Philippines, acknowledged on Friday her loss in one of the most consequential presidential elections in the nation’s history, urging her supporters to accept the results and to keep fighting disinformation. https://t.co/q0WSzDryzh https://t.co/UyKjxe1nz3
Breaking News: Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan, the ailing ruler of the United Arab Emirates, died at 73, a state-run news agency reported. https://t.co/Osg29KnfKj

Breaking News: Video showed Israeli police officers assaulting mourners at the funeral procession of Shireen Abu Akleh, the Palestinian journalist who was killed this week. Israel said they were “forced to act” after rocks were thrown. https://t.co/cmdgKoGhal

In Opinion
Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida "is a leader in a new, Trump-inflected party, but without the character flaws and baggage of the former president," writes Rich Lowry, the editor of National Review. https://t.co/KV1HAGzRfY
Breaking News: Elon Musk said his $44 billion deal to take over Twitter was “on hold” until he gathered more details about spam and fake accounts on the site. https://t.co/z2QtVDKsao

Thailand plans to give away a million cannabis plants to households across the country ahead of a new law that will allow residents to grow weed for their personal medicinal use or as a small-scale commercial enterprise. https://t.co/TOiVQX8W7A https://t.co/qSUJiNUzpE

The declaration by Finland’s leaders that they will join NATO — with expectations that neighboring Sweden would soon do the same — could now reshape a strategic balance in Europe that has prevailed for decades. https://t.co/P3tau96Mqd

The five-year wait for a new album by Kendrick Lamar — the Pulitzer-anointed, voice-of-a-generation rapper — is finally over.
"Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers" is here. https://t.co/j5Ux0GUbTQ

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky on Thursday single-handedly delayed a bipartisan effort to quickly send $40 billion in aid to Ukraine, which Congress had tried to fast-track amid the escalating brutality of Russia’s war. https://t.co/R6ndCo1NKh

President Biden, anticipating the grim milestone of one million lives lost to Covid in the U.S., will order flags at the White House and all federal buildings to be flown at half-staff until Monday. https://t.co/9dtZZHJ2ud

The bodies of more than 1,000 civilians have been recovered in areas north of Kyiv that were occupied by Russian forces, the UN said.
“The figures will continue to increase,” the UN’s human rights chief said. https://t.co/Ce64xCi7Tj

Breaking News: Federal prosecutors have begun a grand jury investigation into whether classified White House documents that ended up at Donald Trump’s Florida home were mishandled, according to two people briefed on the matter. https://t.co/a8nvLkYM96

German electronics giant Siemens is exiting Russia after about 170 years of business there, the latest in a long list of businesses to leave the country since its invasion of Ukraine. The company said it lost about $625 million after Russian sanctions. https://t.co/hPHWtr1kOq

Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Wednesday proposed a series of tax incentives explicitly aimed at recruiting employers from states that restrict reproductive and LGBTQ rights. https://t.co/U9W1mbiCgC

Thailand plans to give away a million cannabis plants to households across the country. The giveaway comes ahead of a new law that will allow residents to grow weed for their personal medicinal use or as a small-scale commercial enterprise. https://t.co/2qrskRYXoH

Across the U.S., parents say they are rationing food for their babies as they search for more formula. Some are driving hours, only to find empty shelves. Online, private sellers are gouging prices, marketing cans for double or triple their normal price. https://t.co/V5d68nEqbR
Breaking News: Astronomers captured the first image of the black hole at the center of our galaxy, using the powerful Event Horizon Telescope. https://t.co/nLMc6DCRTF https://t.co/jylWp5gOVs

One of the biggest donors to the UK's Conservative Party is suspected of secretly funneling $630,225 to the party from a Russian account, a bank alert showed. The cash was part of a fund-raising blitz that helped propel the party to victory in 2019. https://t.co/OQsW2M3cMq

“I’ve got a serious situation here. My pilot has gone incoherent, and I have no idea how to fly the airplane.” A passenger without any flying experience safely landed a private plane at a Florida airport after the pilot had a medical issue, the FAA said. https://t.co/bq46AGzS5Y
Breaking News: Finland’s leaders announced their support for applying to join NATO. The move was expected, and was prompted by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/EheOFOxvd1
Breaking News: North Korea reported its first outbreak of the coronavirus and ordered all of its cities and counties to lock down. https://t.co/e6AjrJKxvt

Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian American journalist for Al Jazeera, was shot and killed in the West Bank early Wednesday, the Palestinian Health Ministry said. The circumstances surrounding the shooting were not immediately clear. https://t.co/k45YD1MJRe
Breaking News: Senate Republicans used a filibuster to block a bill to safeguard abortion rights, thwarting Democrats’ effort to enshrine Roe v. Wade in federal law. https://t.co/zgJmZuoWyK

A passenger without any flying experience safely landed a private plane on Tuesday after the pilot had a medical issue. “I’ve got a serious situation here,” the passenger said to an air-traffic controller who helped him successfully land the plane. https://t.co/KirYe2g684 https://t.co/o05dBpz0Z8

Maria Alyokhina, the activist and Pussy Riot band leader, escaped from Russia disguised as a food courier to evade the police, as President Vladimir Putin cracked down harder to snuff out any criticism of his war in Ukraine. https://t.co/QnF0enD2fA https://t.co/tqgBeChqgE

Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian American reporter who was killed in the West Bank on Wednesday, was a household name across the Middle East. "Shireen was a trailblazer," said Dalia Hatuqa, her friend and a fellow journalist. https://t.co/Ak1Ntg8oMs

Louisiana’s governor said he opposed pending legislation that would classify abortion as homicide and make it possible for prosecutors to bring criminal cases against women who end a pregnancy. He said he would veto the bill if passed by state lawmakers. https://t.co/DnJwXjgho3 https://t.co/p3YQxvbYy0

Sen. Joe Manchin says he opposes Democrats' abortion rights legislation, depriving his party of a simple majority to pass it if were brought to the floor. But even if he supported it, Democrats lack the 60 votes needed to overcome a Republican filibuster. https://t.co/V0gUR4tmPA

A 21-year-old Russian soldier accused of fatally shooting a 62-year-old civilian on a bicycle will be the first Russian service member to stand trial in Ukraine for war crimes since the invasion, Ukraine’s prosecutor general said on Wednesday. https://t.co/m9FnN9DmHi

As Senate Democrats push forward to force a test vote on legislation to turn abortion rights into law, Sen. Patrick Leahy of Vermont pointed out that the debate over abortion rights is happening in an institution that is still dominated by men. https://t.co/EhqddIyVRU https://t.co/Lfafdaou41
Breaking News: Over 500 Native American children died at U.S. schools where they were forced to live between 1819 and 1969, an initial federal inquiry found. https://t.co/C3C3nnmiZo

Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian American journalist for Al Jazeera, was shot and killed in the West Bank early Wednesday, the Palestinian health ministry said. The circumstances surrounding the shooting were not immediately clear. https://t.co/qvLIaWKUcM

Queen Elizabeth II was unable to deliver her speech at the State Opening of Parliament on Tuesday because she was having trouble walking, the palace said. It was the first time she had formally ceded her responsibilities to her heir, Prince Charles. https://t.co/s1pOsGsT8O https://t.co/mdj9tOeKaA
Russia has long seen Bulgaria as its most ardent and reliable friend in Europe. But since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, relations have soured rapidly. https://t.co/t5oIUz8n6E https://t.co/OuJrHU9grp

The Senate confirmed Lisa Cook as a Federal Reserve governor on Tuesday, making her the first Black woman to hold that influential policy post. Her confirmation came after Vice President Kamala Harris broke a 50-to-50 tie in the Senate. https://t.co/IwGv3D85IA
Jim Pillen, a University of Nebraska regent endorsed by Gov. Pete Ricketts, beat a GOP rival backed by Donald Trump in the Republican primary for Nebraska governor. https://t.co/RPh1OpIp3Y
Breaking News: Al Jazeera said one of its journalists was killed in the West Bank city of Jenin during clashes between Israeli forces and Palestinian gunmen. https://t.co/DGzZEiXtnm

Across the U.S., mothers say they are rationing food for their babies as they search for more formula. Some are driving hours, only to find empty shelves. Online, private sellers are gouging prices, marketing cans for double or triple their normal price. https://t.co/ZtajH5TJYl

Breaking News: Gun deaths reached the highest level ever recorded in the U.S. in 2020, the CDC reported on Tuesday. Gun-related homicides, in particular, rose by 35%, a surge that exacted an unprecedented toll on Black men, researchers said. https://t.co/A5POzyavKZ
The Guggenheim Museum in New York and the National Gallery in London are removing the Sackler name from their walls over the family’s ties to the opioid crisis. https://t.co/5sd2t8nRyt
